Story: sometimes i wished to express my sensations in my own mode  but the uncouth and inarticulate sounds which broke from me frightened me into silence again.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the moon had disappeared from the night  and again  with a lessened form  showed itself  while i still remained in the forest.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: my sensations had by this time become distinct  and my mind received every day additional ideas.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: my eyes became accustomed to the light and to perceive objects in their right forms  i distinguished the insect from the herb  and by degrees  one herb from another.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i found that the sparrow uttered none but harsh notes  whilst those of the blackbird and thrush were sweet and enticing.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: one day  when i was oppressed by cold  i found a fire which had been left by some wandering beggars  and was overcome with delight at the warmth i experienced from it.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: in my joy i thrust my hand into the live embers  but quickly drew it out again with a cry of pain.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: how strange  i thought  that the same cause should produce such opposite effects  i examined the materials of the fire  and to my joy found it to be composed of wood.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i quickly collected some branches  but they were wet and would not burn.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i was pained at this and sat still watching the operation of the fire.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the wet wood which i had placed near the heat dried and itself became inflamed.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i reflected on this  and by touching the various branches  i discovered the cause and busied myself in collecting a great quantity of wood  that i might dry it and have a plentiful supply of fire.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: when night came on and brought sleep with it  i was in the greatest fear lest my fire should be extinguished.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i covered it carefully with dry wood and leaves and placed wet branches upon it  and then  spreading my cloak  i lay on the ground and sank into sleep.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: it was morning when i awoke  and my first care was to visit the fire.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i uncovered it  and a gentle breeze quickly fanned it into a flame.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i observed this also and contrived a fan of branches  which roused the embers when they were nearly extinguished.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: when night came again i found  with pleasure  that the fire gave light as well as heat and that the discovery of this element was useful to me in my food  for i found some of the offals that the travellers had left had been roasted  and tasted much more savoury than the berries i gathered from the trees.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i tried  therefore  to dress my food in the same manner  placing it on the live embers.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i found that the berries were spoiled by this operation  and the nuts and roots much improved.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: food  however  became scarce  and i often spent the whole day searching in vain for a few acorns to assuage the pangs of hunger.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: when i found this  i resolved to quit the place that i had hitherto inhabited  to seek for one where the few wants i experienced would be more easily satisfied.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: in this emigration i exceedingly lamented the loss of the fire which i had obtained through accident and knew not how to reproduce it.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i gave several hours to the serious consideration of this difficulty  but i was obliged to relinquish all attempt to supply it  and wrapping myself up in my cloak  i struck across the wood towards the setting sun.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i passed three days in these rambles and at length discovered the open country.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: a great fall of snow had taken place the night before  and the fields were of one uniform white  the appearance was disconsolate  and i found my feet chilled by the cold damp substance that covered the ground.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: it was about seven in the morning  and i longed to obtain food and shelter  at length i perceived a small hut  on a rising ground  which had doubtless been built for the convenience of some shepherd.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: this was a new sight to me  and i examined the structure with great curiosity.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: finding the door open  i entered.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: an old man sat in it  near a fire  over which he was preparing his breakfast.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: he turned on hearing a noise  and perceiving me  shrieked loudly  and quitting the hut  ran across the fields with a speed of which his debilitated form hardly appeared capable.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: his appearance  different from any i had ever before seen  and his flight somewhat surprised me.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: but i was enchanted by the appearance of the hut  here the snow and rain could not penetrate  the ground was dry  and it presented to me then as exquisite and divine a retreat as pand  monium appeared to the d  mons of hell after their sufferings in the lake of fire.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i greedily devoured the remnants of the shepherd   s breakfast  which consisted of bread  cheese  milk  and wine  the latter  however  i did not like.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: then  overcome by fatigue  i lay down among some straw and fell asleep.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: it was noon when i awoke  and allured by the warmth of the sun  which shone brightly on the white ground  i determined to recommence my travels  and  depositing the remains of the peasant   s breakfast in a wallet i found  i proceeded across the fields for several hours  until at sunset i arrived at a village.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: how miraculous did this appear  the huts  the neater cottages  and stately houses engaged my admiration by turns.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the vegetables in the gardens  the milk and cheese that i saw placed at the windows of some of the cottages  allured my appetite.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: one of the best of these i entered  but i had hardly placed my foot within the door before the children shrieked  and one of the women fainted.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the whole village was roused  some fled  some attacked me  until  grievously bruised by stones and many other kinds of missile weapons  i escaped to the open country and fearfully took refuge in a low hovel  quite bare  and making a wretched appearance after the palaces i had beheld in the village.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: this hovel however  joined a cottage of a neat and pleasant appearance  but after my late dearly bought experience  i dared not enter it.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: my place of refuge was constructed of wood  but so low that i could with difficulty sit upright in it.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: no wood  however  was placed on the earth  which formed the floor  but it was dry  and although the wind entered it by innumerable chinks  i found it an agreeable asylum from the snow and rain.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: here  then  i retreated and lay down happy to have found a shelter  however miserable  from the inclemency of the season  and still more from the barbarity of man.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: as soon as morning dawned i crept from my kennel  that i might view the adjacent cottage and discover if i could remain in the habitation i had found.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: it was situated against the back of the cottage and surrounded on the sides which were exposed by a pig sty and a clear pool of water.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: one part was open  and by that i had crept in  but now i covered every crevice by which i might be perceived with stones and wood  yet in such a manner that i might move them on occasion to pass out  all the light i enjoyed came through the sty  and that was sufficient for me.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: having thus arranged my dwelling and carpeted it with clean straw  i retired  for i saw the figure of a man at a distance  and i remembered too well my treatment the night before to trust myself in his power.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i had first  however  provided for my sustenance for that day by a loaf of coarse bread  which i purloined  and a cup with which i could drink more conveniently than from my hand of the pure water which flowed by my retreat.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the floor was a little raised  so that it was kept perfectly dry  and by its vicinity to the chimney of the cottage it was tolerably warm.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: being thus provided  i resolved to reside in this hovel until something should occur which might alter my determination.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: it was indeed a paradise compared to the bleak forest  my former residence  the rain dropping branches  and dank earth.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i ate my breakfast with pleasure and was about to remove a plank to procure myself a little water when i heard a step  and looking through a small chink  i beheld a young creature  with a pail on her head  passing before my hovel.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the girl was young and of gentle demeanour  unlike what i have since found cottagers and farmhouse servants to be.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: yet she was meanly dressed  a coarse blue petticoat and a linen jacket being her only garb  her fair hair was plaited but not adorned  she looked patient yet sad.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: i lost sight of her  and in about a quarter of an hour she returned bearing the pail  which was now partly filled with milk.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: as she walked along  seemingly incommoded by the burden  a young man met her  whose countenance expressed a deeper despondence.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: uttering a few sounds with an air of melancholy  he took the pail from her head and bore it to the cottage himself.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: she followed  and they disappeared.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: presently i saw the young man again  with some tools in his hand  cross the field behind the cottage  and the girl was also busied  sometimes in the house and sometimes in the yard.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: on examining my dwelling  i found that one of the windows of the cottage had formerly occupied a part of it  but the panes had been filled up with wood.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: in one of these was a small and almost imperceptible chink through which the eye could just penetrate.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: through this crevice a small room was visible  whitewashed and clean but very bare of furniture.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: in one corner  near a small fire  sat an old man  leaning his head on his hands in a disconsolate attitude.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the young girl was occupied in arranging the cottage  but presently she took something out of a drawer  which employed her hands  and she sat down beside the old man  who  taking up an instrument  began to play and to produce sounds sweeter than the voice of the thrush or the nightingale.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: it was a lovely sight  even to me  poor wretch who had never beheld aught beautiful before.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the silver hair and benevolent countenance of the aged cottager won my reverence  while the gentle manners of the girl enticed my love.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: he played a sweet mournful air which i perceived drew tears from the eyes of his amiable companion  of which the old man took no notice  until she sobbed audibly  he then pronounced a few sounds  and the fair creature  leaving her work  knelt at his feet.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: he raised her and smiled with such kindness and affection that i felt sensations of a peculiar and overpowering nature  they were a mixture of pain and pleasure  such as i had never before experienced  either from hunger or cold  warmth or food  and i withdrew from the window  unable to bear these emotions.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: soon after this the young man returned  bearing on his shoulders a load of wood.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the girl met him at the door  helped to relieve him of his burden  and taking some of the fuel into the cottage  placed it on the fire  then she and the youth went apart into a nook of the cottage  and he showed her a large loaf and a piece of cheese.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: she seemed pleased and went into the garden for some roots and plants  which she placed in water  and then upon the fire.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: she afterwards continued her work  whilst the young man went into the garden and appeared busily employed in digging and pulling up roots.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: after he had been employed thus about an hour  the young woman joined him and they entered the cottage together.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the old man had  in the meantime  been pensive  but on the appearance of his companions he assumed a more cheerful air  and they sat down to eat.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the meal was quickly dispatched.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the young woman was again occupied in arranging the cottage  the old man walked before the cottage in the sun for a few minutes  leaning on the arm of the youth.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: nothing could exceed in beauty the contrast between these two excellent creatures.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: one was old  with silver hairs and a countenance beaming with benevolence and love  the younger was slight and graceful in his figure  and his features were moulded with the finest symmetry  yet his eyes and attitude expressed the utmost sadness and despondency.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the old man returned to the cottage  and the youth  with tools different from those he had used in the morning  directed his steps across the fields.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: night quickly shut in  but to my extreme wonder  i found that the cottagers had a means of prolonging light by the use of tapers  and was delighted to find that the setting of the sun did not put an end to the pleasure i experienced in watching my human neighbours.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: in the evening the young girl and her companion were employed in various occupations which i did not understand  and the old man again took up the instrument which produced the divine sounds that had enchanted me in the morning.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: so soon as he had finished  the youth began  not to play  but to utter sounds that were monotonous  and neither resembling the harmony of the old man   s instrument nor the songs of the birds  i since found that he read aloud  but at that time i knew nothing of the science of words or letters.

Title: Frankenstein
Story: the family  after having been thus occupied for a short time  extinguished their lights and retired  as i conjectured  to rest.
